title: DSCI 522 Lab Slides
text:
Available Slides

Lab 1 Introduction - Introduction to reproducible workflows, lab policies, and getting started

title: DSCI 522 Lab Slides
text:
About the Course
DSCI 522 focuses on reproducible and trustworthy data science workflows. Students learn best practices for:

Version control with Git and GitHub
Collaborative data science projects
Reproducible analysis pipelines
Documentation and communication
Code review and empathy in pull requests

title: DSCI 522 Lab Slides
text:
Instructor
Sky (Kehan) Sheng
University of British Columbia
www.skysheng.io

title: DSCI 522 Lab 1
text:
Lab Policies üìã


Attendance is mandatory - Come to class!
Grade recovery: Fix problems by next week ‚Üí get 50% of grade back
Communication: English only during lab sessions
Platforms: Use only designated platforms (no mini groups)

title: DSCI 522
text: Group Expectations üë•

title: DSCI 522
text:
Ice Breaking Activity ‚ùÑÔ∏è
Time to get to know each other!

Share your name and background
One fun fact about yourself







What do you expect from your team?



Are you a last-minute genius? procrastinator? planner?
What is your strength (e.g., planning, leadership, proof-reading, etc)?
Share your experience when a group project went horribly wrong
Share your experience when a group project went extremely well
Do you prefer written or verbal communication?

title: DSCI 522
text:
Different Workflows üîÑ

Everyone has a different workflow
That‚Äôs okay! Learn from each other
Focus on simple projects first
Build complexity gradually







What do you expect from your team?


Talk to your group members:

Are you a last-minute genius? procrastinator? planner?
What are your past experiences of when a group project went horribly wrong?
What are your past experiences of when a group project went extremely well?
Do you prefer written or verbal communication?

title: DSCI 522 Lab 1
text:
Lab Structure (Today) ‚è∞

First 30 minutes:

Demo of individual assignment
Questions and clarifications



Remaining time:

Work on your project
Collaborate with your group
Get help as needed

title: DSCI 522
text:
Using AI Tools ü§ñ






Important Guidelines



AI tools are allowed, but you must include proper acknowledgement in your code.
Revisit MDS genAI use policy if you are in doubt.
Document which tool you used, how you interacted with it, what is your prompts, how do you verify the output, etc.
Everyone in your team holds the equal responsibility for the code and documentation you submit as a group.

title: DSCI 522
text:
Today‚Äôs Goal: MVP üéØ


Complete the Simplest Minimum Viable Product
Groups that finish get:

üåü Stickers
üìÑ Posit cheatsheet









Note


Focus on completion, not perfection!

title: DSCI 522
text:
Analysis Guidelines üìä






Keep It Simple!



Classification OR regression only
Don‚Äôt use crazy models
This is NOT for job interviews
Save complex analyses for after class

title: DSCI 522
text:
Empathy in Pull Requests üíô

Writing good PRs is a skill!


Read: On Empathy & Pull Requests


Key points:

Be clear and descriptive
Be kind and constructive
Think about the reviewer

title: DSCI 522
text:
README Best Practices üìù
Your README should include:


Project description
How to run the analysis
Estimated time if analysis takes long
Dependencies and requirements

title: DSCI 522
text:

text:

title: DSCI 522
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Lab Attendence Policies

Lab attendance is mandatory - Come to lab!



‚ÄºÔ∏è Students are expected to attend 100% of their scheduled lab hours and attendance will be taken at the beginning of each lab session. Students must make formal requests for academic concession in the event that they cannot attend a lab session by filling out the academic concession form and sending it to the course instructor. Applying for academic concession does not promise the granting of academic concession. Each application will be evaluated in the context of UBC‚Äôs Academic concession policy. Students missing more than 20% of the total scheduled lab hours for a course without having received an academic concession will receive a possible maximum course grade of 50% and an ‚ÄúF‚Äù standing for the course on the transcript. For all other policies, please see the general MDS policies.

title: DSCI 522
text:
üó£Ô∏è Communications

English only in all group discussions to ensure everyone is involved!
‚ùå Do NOT use these platforms: Below is just a list of examples, not exhaustive list:

title: DSCI 522
text:
‚ùå Do NOT Use These Platforms
Below is just a list of examples, not exhaustive list:

title: DSCI 522
text:
‚úÖ Use These Platforms









GitHub Issues (Preferred)







Slack Group Messages












Why GitHub Issues?



Transparent and trackable: TAs and instructors can see communications and contributions
Everyone is included in the loop










No Mini Groups!


EVERYONE must be involved in conversations. Do not create smaller subgroups within your team.
üíô It‚Äôs ok you have your favorite person, but this is a professional setting. Please be fair, collaborative, and inclusive for the group project! Nobody wants to feel left behind or isolated.

title: DSCI 522
text:
AI Tools Policyü§ñ






Important Guidelines



AI tools are allowed, but you must include proper acknowledgement in your code.
Revisit MDS genAI use policy if you are in doubt.
Document which tool you used, how you interacted with it, what is your prompts, how do you verify the output, etc.
Everyone in your team holds the equal responsibility for the code and documentation you submit as a group.
If genAI tool is used but not acknowledged, everyone in your team will face consequences of academic misconduct.

title: DSCI 522
text:
Equal Contribution

Everyone should contribute equally to all aspects of the project (e.g., code, writing, project management). This should be evidenced by a roughly equal number of commits, pull request reviews and participation in communication via GitHub issues.
The full expectations are written out at the end of your milestone 1 assignment.

title: DSCI 522
text:
‚úÖ Use GitHub Issues for Communication

















Why GitHub Issues?



Transparent and trackable: TAs and instructors can see communications and contributions
Everyone is included in the loop










No Mini Groups!


EVERYONE must be involved in conversations. Do not create smaller subgroups within your team.
üíô It‚Äôs ok you have your favorite person, but this is a professional setting. Please be fair, collaborative, and inclusive for the group project! Nobody wants to feel left behind or isolated üò¢.

title: DSCI 522
text:
Different Work Styles

Everyone has a different work style
The smartest person in the room is the room itself.
Everyone has their unique talents and weaknesses. Learn from each other.

title: DSCI 522
text:
üôè SIMPLE, SIMPLE SIMPLE!!

Focus on building a simple project first
Groups that achieve a MVP (Minimum Viable Product) at the end of the lab will get stickers and Posit cheatsheet!
